metadata.videoTitle: The Science & Treatment of Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD)

proposition: The relationship between hormones and Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) has been relatively underexplored compared to stress-related disorders like anxiety and depression.
A study on neurosteroid levels in patients with OCD found some intriguing results regarding hormone levels in individuals with the disorder.
In females with OCD, there were notably elevated levels of cortisol and DHEA.
Cortisol and DHEA are associated with the stress response system.
Male patients with OCD showed increased cortisol levels alongside significant reductions in testosterone.
These results highlight the interplay between cortisol and testosterone in male patients with OCD.
The study shed some light on the potential impact of hormones on the neurotransmitter GABA.
Neurotransmitter GABA plays a crucial role in regulating neural activity and anxiety levels.
